summary: The NVIDIA Drivers page provides access to various drivers and software updates for NVIDIA products. It includes links to regional websites for localized content and pricing, as well as a main menu with categories such as Products, Cloud Services, Data Center, Embedded Systems, Gaming and Creating, Graphics Cards and GPUs, Laptops, Networking, and Professional Workstations. The page also features detailed descriptions and links to various NVIDIA technologies and solutions, including AI-driven platforms, cloud computing, and high-performance computing.

The page provides an overview of NVIDIA's various products and solutions, including CPU architectures, platforms for AI and HPC, embedded systems, gaming and creating tools, graphics cards and GPUs, laptops, networking solutions, professional workstations, software, and tools. It also includes sections on AI, cloud and data center solutions, design and simulation, high-performance computing, robotics and edge AI, autonomous vehicles, and industry-specific solutions.

The page includes links to detailed information about specific products and technologies such as the Grace CPU, HGX Platform, IGX Platform, MGX Platform, OVX Systems, Jetson, DRIVE AGX, Clara AGX, GeForce graphics cards, G-SYNC monitors, DLSS, RTX, Reflex, RTX AI PCs, NVIDIA Studio, GeForce NOW, NVIDIA App, NVIDIA Broadcast App, SHIELD TV, Blackwell Architecture, Hopper Architecture, Ada Lovelace Architecture, NVIDIA RTX PRO, Virtual GPU, and more.

The page provides information on NVIDIA's software solutions, including AI Blueprints, AI Inference, AI Microservices, Automotive DRIVE, Avatar, Cloud-AI Video Streaming, Cybersecurity, Data Science, Decision Optimization, Generative AI, Healthcare, Industrial AI, Intelligent Video Analytics, NVIDIA Mission Control, NVIDIA AI Enterprise Platform, Physical AI, NVIDIA Run:ai, Robotics, Telecommunications, and more.

The page includes tools such as AI Workbench, API Catalog, Data Center Management, GPU Monitoring, Nsight, NGC Catalog, NVIDIA App for Laptops, NVIDIA NGC, Desktop Manager, RTX Accelerated Creative Apps, and Video Conferencing.

The page covers various solutions including AI, cloud and data center, design and simulation, high-performance computing, robotics and edge AI, autonomous vehicles, and industry-specific solutions. It also provides links to detailed information about these solutions.

The page includes sections on Linux drivers, additional drivers, and NVIDIA Virtual GPU customers. It provides links to download drivers and additional software, and information on how to access purchased licenses.
The page includes news and recommendations related to NVIDIA products, such as updates on RTX, DLSS, and new gaming hardware like the GeForce RTX 5060 Ti.

The page provides information about NVIDIA drivers, including details on the RTX 5060 Ti graphics card, gaming hardware, and various download options for different types of drivers. It also includes sections for enterprise customers with Virtual GPU licenses, Linux drivers, and additional driver options like CUDA drivers for Mac, Quadro advanced options, and more.

The page offers download links for popular drivers, including GeForce, NVIDIA System, and NVIDIA RTX drivers. It also provides a login portal for enterprise customers with Virtual GPU software licenses.

The page includes a section for Linux drivers, noting that many Linux distributions provide their own packages of the NVIDIA Linux Graphics Driver, which may interact better with the distribution's framework.

The page lists additional driver options such as NVIDIA CUDA drivers for Mac, Quadro advanced options, NVIDIA PhysX system software, 3D Vision driver downloads, Quadro Sync firmware, and HGX software.

The page provides information on different types of drivers, including Production Branch/Studio drivers for optimal stability and performance, and New Feature Branch (NFB)/Quadro New Feature (QNF) drivers for access to new features and bug fixes.

The page explains the difference between various driver types, such as 'All' drivers, 'Game Ready Drivers' for gaming, and 'Studio Drivers' for creative applications. It also provides links to identify graphics card models and understand the differences between NVIDIA RTX, GeForce, and Quadro.

The page includes company information, such as links to 'About Us', 'Company Overview', 'Investors', 'Venture Capital', 'NVIDIA Foundation', 'Research', 'Corporate Sustainability', 'Technologies', and 'Careers'.

The page provides news and events information, including links to the 'Newsroom', 'Company Blog', 'Technical Blog', 'Webinars', 'Stay Informed', 'Events Calendar', 'GTC AI Conference', and 'NVIDIA On-Demand'.

The page lists popular links such as 'Developers', 'Partners', 'Executive Insights', 'Startups and VCs', 'NVIDIA Connect for ISVs', 'Documentation', 'Technical Training', 'Training for IT Professionals', and 'Professional Services for Data Science'.

The page includes social media links for following NVIDIA on Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Twitter, and YouTube. It also provides links for selecting the location, privacy policy, terms of service, accessibility, corporate policies, product security, and contact information.
The page lists various locations in the Americas, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East, providing links to specific country pages.

The page provides information on cookie usage, including required cookies for site functionality, performance cookies for analytics, personalization cookies for enhanced web experience, and advertising cookies for targeted ads. It also includes a cookie settings management section.

Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang announced plans to allow customers to deploy rivals' chips in data centers built around Nvidia technology, giving customers more flexibility and allowing for competition. Huang introduced the NVLink Fusion system, which enables the building of customized AI infrastructure combining Nvidia's high-speed links with semiconductors from other providers. Nvidia also announced various product enhancements, including faster software and chipset setups to speed up AI services, as well as new products such as the RTX Pro Server system and DGX Cloud Lepton software.

Nvidia's move to open up its AI server ecosystem comes as competitors and partners are racing to develop their own AI semiconductors. Major customers like Microsoft and Amazon are designing their own bespoke parts, which could make Nvidia less essential to data centers. Nvidia has already signed up several partners, including MediaTek, Marvell Technology, and Alchip Technologies, to create custom AI chips that work with Nvidia processor-based gear.

Nvidia's smaller-scale computers, the DGX Spark and DGX Station, will be offered by a broader range of suppliers starting this summer. Local partners like Acer and Gigabyte Technology are joining the list of companies offering these portable and desktop devices. Nvidia also introduced new software for robots and detailed blueprints to help corporations build AI factories. Additionally, Nvidia launched DGX Cloud Lepton software to help cloud computing providers automate the process of hooking up AI developers with the necessary computers.

The NVIDIA Story page provides an overview of NVIDIA, inviting users to learn more about the company and its journey. It includes links to various resources such as the NVIDIA Story, a webpage about NVIDIA, a brochure, and a video. The page also includes social media links and information about cookies and privacy policies.
The page includes recommended content for users, such as a webpage about NVIDIA, a brochure titled 'NVIDIA Story', a video titled 'NVIDIA Story Video', and a PDF brochure titled 'NVIDIA In Brief'.

The page discusses the use of cookies by NVIDIA and third-party partners to enhance website experience, improve performance, and assist in marketing efforts. Users can manage their cookie settings and learn more about the privacy practices through provided links.

The cookie settings section explains the different types of cookies used: Required Cookies, Performance Cookies, Personalization Cookies, and Advertising Cookies. Users can adjust their settings for each category.

Nvidia has announced a new technology called 'NVLink Fusion' that allows customers and partners to use non-Nvidia CPUs and GPUs in tandem with Nvidia's products and NVLink. This program aims to keep Nvidia at the center of AI development by providing added flexibility and competitiveness in the AI infrastructure market. The announcement was made by Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang at Computex 2025 in Taiwan. Key partners for NVLink Fusion include MediaTek, Marvell, Alchip, Astera Labs, Synopsys, and Cadence. The technology is expected to broaden Nvidia's industry footprint and foster deeper collaboration with custom CPU developers and ASIC designers.

The NVIDIA GeForce Drivers page provides access to the latest drivers for NVIDIA GeForce graphics cards. It includes a variety of products and solutions related to gaming, AI, data center, and professional workstations. The page also offers information on cloud services, embedded systems, and networking solutions. Users can find drivers for different types of GPUs, including those for gaming, professional workstations, and data centers. The page also includes links to various software tools and solutions for AI, data science, and high-performance computing.

The page provides information on AI-powered computing for medical devices and imaging, gaming, and creating with GeForce Graphics Cards, RTX graphics cards, and laptops. It also covers G-SYNC monitors, DLSS technology, RTX platform, Reflex technology, AI PCs, NVIDIA Studio, GeForce NOW cloud gaming, NVIDIA App, NVIDIA Broadcast App, and SHIELD TV. Additionally, it includes details on graphics cards and GPUs, laptops, networking, professional workstations, software, tools, and various solutions for AI, cloud and data center, design and simulation, high-performance computing, robotics and edge AI, autonomous vehicles, and industries.

The page includes sections on GeForce drivers, automatic driver updates, manual driver search, and driver results. It provides information on GeForce Game Ready Drivers and NVIDIA Studio Drivers, and includes links to download drivers and visit forums for driver-related discussions.

The page provides information on NVIDIA GeForce drivers for various GPU series, including 500, 400, 300, 200, 100, 9, 8, 7, 6, and 5 FX series. It also lists specific laptop GPUs like the RTX 5090, 5080, 5070 Ti, and 5070. The page allows users to select their GPU series, operating system, language, and driver type (Standard or DCH). It also provides options for different download types such as Game Ready Driver and Studio Driver. The page includes links to driver forums, news, and community resources.

The page explains the difference between Game Ready Drivers and Studio Drivers. Game Ready Drivers are optimized for gaming, providing day-of-launch support for new games, patches, and DLCs. Studio Drivers are tailored for creative applications like video editing, animation, photography, graphic design, and livestreaming. The page also provides instructions on how to identify the GPU product type and driver type installed on a system.

The page includes links to various NVIDIA products such as graphics cards, laptops, G-SYNC monitors, and GeForce NOW cloud gaming. It also provides access to community forums, news, and developer resources. Additionally, it offers support links for drivers, purchase support, and technical support.

The page lists social media links for NVIDIA GeForce, including Facebook, Instagram, TikTok, Twitch, and Twitter. It also provides links to NVIDIA's privacy policy, terms of service, accessibility, corporate policies, product security, and contact information.

The page includes a list of available locations for NVIDIA services, covering regions in the Americas, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East. It also provides links to specific country pages for localized content.

The page discusses the use of cookies and tracking technologies by NVIDIA and its third-party partners. It explains the different types of cookies used, including required, performance, personalization, and advertising cookies. Users can manage their cookie settings and consent to the use of cookies as described in the cookie policy.
